company.name: Credit Bureau Center, LLC
company.business_description: Credit Bureau Center operates websites offering credit monitoring services and purportedly free credit scores and reports. The company uses online marketing strategies, including websites such as eFreeScore.com and CreditUpdates.com, to attract consumers to sign up for credit monitoring services.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5 of the Restore Online Shoppers' Confidence Act (ROSCA), 15 U.S.C. § 8404; Section 621(a)(1) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a)(1); Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 4 of ROSCA, 15 U.S.C. § 8403; Section 612(g) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681j(g)

complaint.factual_background: Credit Bureau Center and its affiliates used fake rental property advertisements on Craigslist and fraudulent landlord emails to lure consumers to websites offering supposedly free credit scores and reports. Consumers believed they were obtaining credit reports to tour rental properties, but were instead enrolled in a $29.94 monthly credit monitoring service without their knowledge or consent. The scheme generated over 500 consumer complaints and millions of dollars in losses.

representations_made.description: Claimed that advertised rental properties were currently available for rent and would be shown to consumers who obtained credit reports
representations_made.quoted_text: a residential property described in an online ad is currently available for rent from someone consumers can contact through that ad; and the property will be shown to consumers who obtain their credit reports and scores through the Credit Bureau Center Defendants' website.

representations_made.description: Represented that they were offering consumers their credit scores and reports for free
representations_made.quoted_text: the Credit Bureau Center Defendants have represented, directly or indirectly, expressly or by implication, that they are offering consumers their credit scores and reports for free.

counts.title: False Rental Property Advertisements
counts.representation: Defendants represented that residential properties described in online ads were currently available for rent and would be shown to consumers who obtained their credit reports through the Credit Bureau Center Defendants' website
counts.fact: The residential properties described in the online ads were not currently available for rent from someone consumers could contact through the ads, and the properties were not shown to consumers who obtained their credit reports through the Credit Bureau Center Defendants' website
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendants' representations as set forth in Paragraph 38 of this Complaint are false and misleading and constitute deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: Deceptive Free Credit Score Offer
counts.representation: The Credit Bureau Center Defendants represented that they were offering consumers their credit scores and reports for free
counts.fact: The Credit Bureau Center Defendants failed to disclose or disclose adequately material terms including: automatic enrollment in a negative option continuity plan with additional charges; requirement to affirmatively cancel before trial period ends; use of card information to charge consumers monthly; costs of $29.94 per month; and cancellation procedures
counts.conclusion: The Credit Bureau Center Defendants' failure to disclose or disclose adequately the material information described in Paragraph 42, above, in light of the representation described in Paragraph 41, above, constitutes a deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: Failure to Disclose Material Terms (ROSCA)
counts.representation: The Credit Bureau Center Defendants charged or attempted to charge consumers for credit monitoring service through a negative option feature
counts.fact: The Credit Bureau Center Defendants failed to clearly and conspicuously disclose all material terms of the transaction before obtaining consumers' billing information
counts.conclusion: The Credit Bureau Center Defendants' acts or practices, as described in Paragraph 49 above, constitute a violation of Section 4(1) of ROSCA, 15 U.S.C. § 8403(1), and are therefore a violation of a rule promulgated under Section 18 of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 57a.

counts.title: Failure to Obtain Express Informed Consent (ROSCA)
counts.representation: The Credit Bureau Center Defendants charged or attempted to charge consumers for credit monitoring service through a negative option feature
counts.fact: The Credit Bureau Center Defendants failed to obtain consumers' express informed consent before charging their credit card, debit card, bank account, or other financial account for the credit monitoring service
counts.conclusion: The Credit Bureau Center Defendants' acts or practices, as described in Paragraph 51 above, constitute a violation of Section 4(2) of ROSCA, 15 U.S.C. § 8403(2), and are therefore a violation of a rule promulgated under Section 18 of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 57a.

counts.title: Failure to Display Required Free Credit Report Disclosure
counts.representation: The Credit Bureau Center Defendants operated websites offering free credit reports including eFreeScore.com and CreditUpdates.com
counts.fact: The Credit Bureau Center Defendants operated these websites without displaying across the top of each page that mentions free credit reports, and across the top of each page of the ordering process, the prominent disclosure required by the Free Reports Rule to inform consumers of their right to obtain a free credit report from AnnualCreditReport.com or (877) 322-8228
counts.conclusion: The Credit Bureau Center Defendants' acts or practices, as described in Paragraph 60 above, violate Section 612(g)(1) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681j(g)(1), and the Free Reports Rule, 12 C.F.R. § 1022.138.

provisions.title: Appellate Decision - Not a Consent Order
provisions.summary: This document is a United States Court of Appeals decision reviewing a district court judgment, not an FTC consent order or federal consent decree with extractable provisions.

requirements.description: This is an appellate court opinion analyzing whether the district court properly amended a judgment to impose restitution under ROSCA and Section 19 of the FTCA
requirements.quoted_text: The amended judgment contains one error that requires correction. As we've explained, section 19 is limited to 'such relief as the court finds necessary to redress injury to consumers.' § 57b(b). The judgment directs the Commission to deposit any excess money not used for consumer redress and administrative expenses 'to the U.S. Treasury as disgorgement.' The Commission acknowledged at oral argument that this part of the judgment sweeps beyond the statute. We therefore modify part IX.D of the amended judgment to remove this sentence: 'Any money not used for such equitable relief is to be deposited to the U.S. Treasury as disgorgement.' As modified, the judgment is AFFIRMED.

duration.termination_text: No termination or duration clause found. This is an appellate opinion, not a consent order with a specified term.
